item.content:encoded:
To me, 2018 (the year I was/am off on maternity leave) was the year that VS Code really blew up in popularity.

So although I had switched to Atom from Sublime Text a year or two earlier, I decided to switch AGAIN‚Ä¶ because no one is nearly as obsessed with Atom like they are for VS Code and since now Microsoft owns both editors, I might as well switch to the preferred child.

And since I‚Äôm not working at the moment and have a bit of time during baby naps to nerd out, I got to spend a lot of time researching and getting my setup just right.

I wasn‚Äôt totally sure about writing this blog post because it seems a bit frivolous and self-centered to write about my setup? Especially because there‚Äôs already a zillion similar posts out there already.

BUT I have decided to shut that inner voice of doubt down because:

  1. STFU mean self-talk

and

  1. I really enjoy reading other people‚Äôs posts about their setups. I have read a LOT of them. So obviously there are people (like me) who DO enjoy reading this kind of thing!

First up: The icon

I‚Äôm not usually one to replace app icons, it just seems a bit‚Ä¶ extreme? Like it feels more pure to stick with how the vendor intended it to be. But I really didn‚Äôt like the existing icon and decided to break my usual rule üòÑ (actually, as you can see in the screenshot I went a bit crazy and also updated some of the Finder folders so I guess I am breaking all the rules these days.)

I ended up going with this icon by Lex Tang. It looks pretty good:

OK what about theme?

I‚Äôve long been a fan of Tomorrow Night Eighties in all my editors, but after many years, I thought it was probably time to try something new. Ali Spittel mentioned Dracula and‚Ä¶ Yep, love it.

And extensions

Since I‚Äôm not coding a TON right now I actually don‚Äôt know exactly what will prove to be most useful, but I installed the ones that seem like they make the most sense, and from the limited use I‚Äôve had with them so far, they have been great.

For writing copy, like I am right now

  • :emojisense: ‚Äì Great for quickly inserting an emoji üòÅ I am fine with using the mac keyboard shortcut (‚åò^space) a lot of the time, but since I do also have some muscle memory from Slack and Github I liked the idea of having the colon syntax available to me too. (plus, is it just me or is the mac shortcut kind of buggy sometimes?)
  • Code Spell Checker ‚Äì Sometimes I have typos. It‚Äôs nice having an editor that notifies you of typos.

For writing code

  • ESLint ‚Äì A no‚Äìbrainer if you use ESLint in your code to have your editor auto‚Äìnotify you of transgressions.
  • GitLens ‚Äì if you use Git for version control it‚Äôs nice to have history and diffs displayed right in the editor. Some people LOVE this feature, I‚Äôve always been slightly take‚Äìit‚Äìor‚Äìleave‚Äìit about it but it seems better to have it than not, overall.
  • Path IntelliSense ‚Äì autocompletes filenames for you, which is especially great if you are working with large JS projects that require you to import from files.
  • React PropTypes IntelliSense ‚Äì Autocomplete props when passing props around in React. Handy if you write React code, useless if you don‚Äôt üôÉ
  • SASS IntelliSense ‚Äì I think most devs don‚Äôt use SASS syntax anymore, correct me if I‚Äôm wrong? I rarely see it in the wild these days! But at Flow we still do and I don‚Äôt think we‚Äôll be changing it any time soon, so it‚Äôs nice to have this.
  • SCSS IntelliSense ‚Äì for non-Flow projects I use SCSS most of the time, so need this too!
  • VS Live Share ‚Äì I haven‚Äôt used this yet but I saw it recommended in another blog post (which one: I have forgotten üò¢) and I liked the idea so much I decided to add it in hopes I could one day use it for pair programming.
  • VS Code Vim ‚Äì I am not a hardcore vim user but I like having the shortcuts available to me sometimes. I turned off the setting to switch out of insertion mode on copy though as I found that irritating. As a non power-user of Vim I like being in insertion mode unless I explicitly esc out.

item.title: Going back to work
item.description: I‚Äôm back at work in exactly two months. I will have been off for a year at that point, living a life of leisure (lol üòê) taking care of a‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
I‚Äôm back at work in exactly two months. I will have been off for a year at that point, living a life of leisure (lol üòê) taking care of a baby.

My emotions are mixed!

‚ú® I‚Äôm excited, because I enjoy working (although let‚Äôs be honest, back when I left for maternity leave last year I was also very excited for a break from working üòá) and taking care of a baby is‚Ä¶ well, it‚Äôs not so bad, but it‚Äôs pretty all-consuming so it will be nice to get away and do something else.

‚ú® I‚Äôm also excited because I really like my coworkers and spending time with them is kind of like spending time with friends. Is that sad? Is that weird? Please tell me that it is neither sad nor weird.

üò¢ On the other hand, I‚Äôm sad because I‚Äôm going to be away from Little P so much, and I have never been apart from her for more than an hour or two here and there.

üò¢ AND: Unless I take another year off for another baby (which may or may not happen, both a second baby and my decision for how much time to take for maternity leave ‚Äì husband and I are seriously considering having him take the majority of the leave next time, if there is a next time) this may be the ONLY time in my life when I get such a large chunk of time off work‚Ä¶ until I retire üò¨

üßü‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Finally, going back to work is terrifying for a reason I hadn‚Äôt anticipated: Baby still wakes up multiple times per night, so I am often very sleep deprived and my brain is not firing on all cylinders. This makes me both dumb AND grumpy, a really excellent combination. I don‚Äôt mind subjecting Ben to my stupid, angry self, but I do feel bad doing that to my coworkers. I naively thought that by age one things would be pretty good in the sleep department. OH HOW WRONG I WAS.

So. I‚Äôm not really sure how it‚Äôs all going to go down!

Lucky my employer is excellent and I know they‚Äôll be very supportive during the transition back to work ‚ù§Ô∏è

Still, it will be interesting. Hopefully it is relatively smooth sailing.

In news that is absolutely not news to anyone, juggling a career and kids as a woman is kind of shitty. Your attention is so split between family and work, you‚Äôre sleep deprived, and you have to take time off work every time you have a baby which puts you at a disadvantage for promotions and just staying current in the industry (üôÑ). I know some men might say they have it tough too, and I‚Äôm sure they do, but just looking at my own family situation: I have it WAY worse than my husband does, no doubt. And I‚Äôm so torn, because on the one hand I really love my job and want to pursue it to the fullest, but on the other hand I‚Äôm like ‚ÄúWhen I die, what will I regret more: Time not spent with my children or a career unfulfilled?‚Äù And the answer is pretty obvious in that context.

That said, I am very thankful I am in a situation where I can take a year off. I cannot imagine having to go back to work only a few weeks after giving birth. I would have been a total mess.

I‚Äôll try to write an update on how it all looks in reality once I‚Äôm back and in the swing of things üòä

item.title: Maternity Leave Experimentation
item.description: I‚Äôve been on maternity leave for almost ten months now and I haven‚Äôt really accomplished that much. It‚Äôs not that I went into mat leave with‚Ä¶
item.content:encoded:
I‚Äôve been on maternity leave for almost ten months now and I haven‚Äôt really accomplished that much.

It‚Äôs not that I went into mat leave with any specific expectations ‚Äì but I thought I might do something interesting. And in my daydrams I fantisized about accomplishing a TON, like keeping a perfectly clean house, writing a full-length novel, and learning so many new things about front end development.

In reality:

  • üè† House is usually messy. Sometimes I go crazy and do a bunch of cleaning, but 2 days later it looks terrible again so it‚Äôs pretty demoralizing.
  • üìö I haven‚Äôt done anything super notable, although I have read a lot more fiction that I do most years, which has been pleasant.
  • üíª I have spent some time on Stackoverflow answering questions, which is sort of fun and rewarding when people thank you.
  • üíª I have spent some time contributing to open source, but not much. If you look at my Github profile‚Äôs history you‚Äôd probably roll your eyes and say ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs it?!‚Äù
  • üíª I have also spent a bit of time working on a personal pet project related to my job.
  • üíª I have been blogging very regularly on Life as Rose, but it is a private/personal blog about my daily activities, so nothing to see there!
  • üíª And now my latest project is this, what you are looking at right now! Trying out Gatsby and publishing it on roserobertson.me because this site isn‚Äôt doing anything anyway.
  • üë∂ And of course I have been taking care of my baby!
